title: Policy Implementations
content:
This page details information on policy implementations and how to view them.

Overview

A policy defines the vulnerabilities you need to remediate and the inherited patches available to apply on targeted systems or the list of patches you want to apply.
Policy implementations link the patches defined in a policy (either patches added directly or patches inherited from vulnerabilities) to the Configuration Items (CIs) (Involved CIs) to monitor them.

Policy implementations lifecycle

Policy implementations have a pre-defined workflow representing the lifecycle of every instance within Automation Center. Policy implementations contain the following metaphases:

  • Draft
  • Definition
  • Active
  • Retired

The policy implementation lifecycle has the following transition phases:

policy implementations transitions
Transition phase  Transition type  Description
New > Define Automatic When you fill in the name and policy, the phase moves from New to Define.
Define > Approve Manual This identifies that there is no default approval plan and moves a policy automatically from Define to Active phase.
Approve > Define Manual or Automatic Approve request is rejected.
Approve > Monitor Automatic Policy Implementation approved. A policy implementation in Monitor phase is automatically synchronized to Server Automation if the integration with Server Automation for policy synchronization has been followed.
Monitor > Suspend Manual Suspend policy implementations until you approve the changes. 
Suspend > Monitor Manual Suspend policy implementations until you approve the changes. 
* > Retire Manual Jobs no longer run for this policy.

Draft

The Draft metaphase contains the following phase:

New: Initial phase for a newly created policy implementation, until the instance has the required information.

Definition

The Definition metaphase contains the following phase:

  • Define: The CIs' selection depends on the CIs that you will monitor.
  • Approve: Policy implementation is ready for the approval process.

Active

The Active metaphase contains the following phases:

  • Monitor: You can use approved policy implementation. Jobs can run to monitor the selected CIs. Unable to change the rules.
  • Suspend: You can suspend the policy implementation to change the CIs.

Retired

The Retired metaphase contains the following phase:

Retire: Policy implementation is no longer of interest. Jobs will no longer run.

View policy implementations

To view the policy implementation:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build > Vulnerability & Remediation > Policy Implementations.
  2. To view the full details of a policy implementation, navigate to the details page by clicking the entity’s ID.

Filters

Filters help you filter record lists or define filters for a report. To create a filter, see Filters - Service Management.

Policy implementation details

The policy implementation details contain the following tabs:

General tab

Contains the general information on the policy implementation. The General tab consists of the following fields:

general tab
Field Description
Name The name of the policy.
Description The description of the policy.
Policy The policy that defines the patches.
Owner¹ The person responsible for dealing with the policy implementation.
Owning Group¹ The group responsible for dealing with the policy implementation.

¹ If Owner and Owning Group are not visible (for example, in environments upgraded from 24.3), a user with access to Studio must change the Forms for each entity to make the fields visible.

Workflow tab

Shows the policy implementation instance’s current phase within the lifecycle.

Involved CIs tab

The user-provided list of infrastructure services for which the policy implementation is meant.

If the policy implementation is used for the remediation of the involved CIs (remediation by targeting specific vulnerabilities or desired patches), the Involved CIs list is used as a target list for the actual remediation. 

Discussions tab

Displays discussions related to the policy implementation instance.

History tab

Shows the change history of the policy implementation instance.

Create a policy implementation

To create a new policy implementation:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build > Vulnerability & Remediation > Policy Implementations.
  2. Click  on the Policy Implementations page.
  3. Fill in the following details on the New Policy Implementation page under Policy Implementation Details:
    • Name: Mandatory. Type a unique name for your policy implementation.
    • Description: Optional. Enter a description for your policy implementation.
    • Policy: Mandatory. A policy must be in the Active phase.
  4. Click Save.

Edit a policy implementation

You can edit the policy individually from the Policy Implementation details page or in bulk by selecting multiple policies. You can change the lists of Involved CIs when the Policy is in Define or Suspend phases. 

To edit the policy individually:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build > Vulnerability & Remediation > Policy Implementations.
  2. Click on a policy. The Policy Implementation details page opens.
  3. Edit any of the available fields under the General tab.
  4. Click Save.

To edit policies in bulk:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build > Vulnerability & Remediation > Policy Implementations.
  2. Select multiple policies that you want to edit.
  3. On the right side under Fields, select Add Field. This displays all the fields of the policy you can edit. For example, Name, Description, Data domains, Display Label, Owner, Job Model, and Owner Group.
  4. Select the field and make the changes under New value to assign.
  5. Click Update.

Remediate CIs through a policy implementation

Policy implementation also signifies applying policies on a set of targeted devices tracked under Involved CIs.

Automation Center provides easy integration with Server Automation for agent-based monitoring and target remediation. A policy implementation allows the remediation of the involved CIs by using the underlying systems and mechanisms (for example, Server Automation).

Note that:

  • The Remediate button only becomes available when the user who has access to the policy implementation also has the appropriate edit permissions. The policy implementation must be in monitor phase, and you must also define a Job Model.
  • If you want to remediate your CIs according to the needs and practices of your organization, you must manually create a Job Model. If there is no Active Job Model available under Automation Operations > Job Model, you won't be able to select a Job Model in the dropdown.
  • The way patches are applied to the Involved CIs is controlled by the Job Model. Ensure you select a job model per your needs. For example, if you are using Server Automation to monitor and remediate CIs available in your data center, make sure to use a Job Model that has already been defined to use an automatic task that triggers Operations Orchestration flows offered through Automation Center Vulnerability and Scanners Content Pack to remediate CIs through SA.

For more information on how to properly configure a Job Model, see Job Models - Automation Center.

To remediate CIs by policy implementation:

  1. From the Mega Menu, go to Build > Vulnerability & Remediation > Policy Implementations.
  2. Click on a policy. The Policy Implementation details page opens.
  3. Click the Remediate button.
  4. A pop-up window called Policy Remediation opens. Choose an item in the list and trigger the remediation job by clicking the REMEDIATE button in the pop-up window.
    Not selecting any item in the list will trigger a job for all the Involved CIs defined for the policy implementation.
  5. A green notification message confirms the job is created successfully.
    You can customize the suffix of the job being triggered. By default, a job is created with a name composed of [id of the involved CI] name of the involved CI for which the policy is being triggered. If you provide a suffix in the Policy Remediation pop-up, a job name composed of [id of the involved CI] suffix will be created.
    A red notification message can occur in the event that job triggering is not done properly. To learn more about jobs, see Jobs - Automation Center.
